Just 60 tons payload, but expanding. If they could build one with a hollow at the center of gravity you could launch a rocket from the center. You probably would need to use steam mass accelerator to get it away from the ship before firing mains.

Wrong article? Unless the heavy load is being carried by the UA CEO
United Airlines are expanding into orbital launches? I think that a 727 would have difficulties getting to orbit!
llol, I can't believe that. i did not c&p the au article, must be a beeb glitch. will correct.

The giant one carries 2 cargo containers. That's how many a single train car holds. Freight charges are apparently about $1.98 for 2 containers per mile (3 cents per ton-mile). These clearly have some utility, but I don't see them as being all that common.

I already did a topic about this here:

http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/114457-Towards-the-most-efficient-freight-vehicle

They already left the prototype step, now the commercial design began. They are hiring.

But someone should try to prove than hydrogen airships can be very safe with a not flamable envelope, only then these vehicles will become super cost efficient.
Only if A and B are vast tarmac landing pads and are the actual places where you want to those 66 tons delivered.

Picky-picky. They could actually crane it down. They didn not give any details on their superlift they are making.
